channel.title: INtopBackup
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INtopBackup, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Concern over Google ending ban on AI weapons
item.description: The tech giant previously ruled out applications that were "likely to cause harm".

item.title: USAID is going away, and along with it cocaine-fighting efforts and Amazon rainforest protection

item.title: Sweden searches for answers after country's deadliest shooting
item.description: Police say the motive of the shooter, who killed 10 people on Tuesday, remains unknown.

item.title: USAID staff will be put on leave starting on Friday
item.description: The agency has become a focus of the Trump administration's efforts to cut government spending.

item.title: Seventeen pupils burnt to death in Nigeria school fire
item.description: The fire is said to have broken out in a nearby house and spread to the school while the children were asleep.

item.title: Trump picks Neil Jacobs to head NOAA, a scientist with 'Sharpiegate' ties

item.title: More than 100 women raped and burned alive in DR Congo jailbreak, UN says
item.description: As M23 rebels entered Goma and the city was plunged into chaos, female prisoners were attacked, the UN says.

item.title: U.S. cannabis shoppers face a market flush with illegal weed

item.title: Suspect in custody after 1 killed, 5 wounded in Ohio warehouse shooting
item.description: Police said an employee of a warehouse in a Columbus, Ohio, suburb shot one co-worker to death and wounded five others late Tuesday night.

item.title: NBA writer talks Dončić trade that shocked players and fans
item.description: James Herbert, an NBA writer with CBS Sports, joins "CBS Mornings Plus" to discuss the Luka Dončić trade that shocked the NBA world over the weekend.
